Issues.Title: Ivy: :leave animations trigger when navigating away from component
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Affected Package @angular/animations (presumably) ### Is this a regression? No, happens in all versions of 9.x with Ivy enabled. ### Description When an animation query is specified with `:leave`, it should only fire when an item is added/removed per the documentation. In 9.x with Ivy enabled, however, all `:leave` animations fire whenever the component is navigated away from, even though nothing is being added/removed. This is especially annoying because the new component won't load until the animations have finished. You can disable Ivy in the repro and see that it does what you would expect--`:leave` doesn't fire when navigating away from the component. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-udwujp ## üî• Exception or Error N/A ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 
Angular CLI: 9.1.1
Node: 13.12.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 9.1.1
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Issues.Title: fix(ngcc): do not warn if `paths` mapping does not exist
Issues.Body:
In cc4b813e759f16fb0f4dfa92a0e6464ed768a629 the `getBasePaths()`
function was changed to log a warning if a `basePath()` computed from
the `paths` mappings did not exist. It turns out this is a common and
accepted scenario, so we should not log warnings in this case.

Fixes #36518
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ngcc): do not warn if `paths` mapping does not exist" (#36525)

Issues.Title: fix(language-service): properly evaluate types in comparable expressions
Issues.Body:
This commit fixes how the language service evaluates the compatibility
of types to work with arbitrary union types. As a result, compatibility
checks are now more strict and can catch similarities or differences
more clearly.

```
number|string == string|null  // OK
number|string == number       // OK
number|string == null         // not comparable
number == string              // not comparable
```

Using Ivy as a backend should provide these diagnoses for free, but we
can backfill them for now.

Closes https://github.com/angular/vscode-ng-language-service/issues/723

Issues.Body:

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> This feature request is for @angular/core


### Description
What do you think about enabling Nullish Coalescing also in angular template?

I often write for example something like this:

`<span [title]="variable != null ? variable : ''">`

s.t 
if variable = 3, title = '3'
if variable = 0, title = '0'
if variable = null, title = '', meaning the html tooltip title is hidden

### Describe the solution you'd like
It would be nice in my opinion to write something like:

`<span [title]="checkV ?? ''">`

to obtain the same results with a less verbose syntax.

It may be also helpful in other situations, in template interpolation {{ ... }}, etc

What do you think? Thanks!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Enable Nullish Coalescing operator in angular template" (#36528)

Issues.Title: build: ts-circular-dependencies tool should normalize golden
Issues.Body:
Currently the golden output of the circular-deps tool is purely based
on the order of source files passed to the tool, and on the order and amount
of imports inside source files.

This is actually resulting in deterministic output as running the tool multiple
times without any changes to source files, results in the same output.

*Though* it seems like the tool is too strict and we can avoid a few unnecessary
golden changes if:

* A source file that is part of a cycle is imported earlier (in terms
of how the analyzer visits them). This could result in the cycle path
starting with a different source file. Resulting in unnecessary diff in the golden.
* Source files which are not part of a cycle are imported earlier
(in terms of how the analyzer visits them). This could result in moved
cycle paths in the golden if re-approved.

To fix this, we normalize the cycle path that serves as serializable data
structure for the text-based goldens. Since the paths represents a cycle,
the path can be shifted in a deterministic way so that cycles don't change
unnecessarily in the golden, and to simplify comparison of cycles.

Additionally, we sort the cycles in a deterministic way so that the golden
doesn't change unnecessarily as described in the second bullet point.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: ts-circular-dependencies tool should normalize golden" (#36505)

Issues.Title: build: update matching regex for bazel stamping
Issues.Body:
Previously, the bazel stamping regex only matched on versions
0-9 for major and minor numbers, this update allows for matching
on any number for major, minor or patch.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: update matching regex for bazel stamping" (#36523)

Issues.Title: fix(core): pipes injecting viewProviders when used on a component host node
Issues.Body:
The flag that determines whether something should be able to inject from `viewProviders` is opt-out and the pipes weren't opted out, resulting in them being able to see the `viewProviders` if they're placed on a component host node.

Fixes #36146.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(core): pipes injecting viewProviders when used on a component host node" (#36512)

Issues.Title: fix(dev-infra): fix commit message validation in git worktrees
Issues.Body:
Previously, the `pre-commit-validate` command (used in the `commit-msg` git hook) assumed that the commit message was stored in `.git/COMMIT_EDITMSG` file. This is usually true, but not when using [git worktrees](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-worktree), where `.git` is a file containing the path to the actual git directory.

This commit fixes it by taking advantage of the fact that git passes the actual path of the file holding the commit message to the `commit-msg` hook and husky exposes the arguments passed by git as `$HUSKY_GIT_PARAMS`.

NOTE:
We cannot use the environment variable directly in the `commit-msg` hook command, because environment variables need to be referenced differently on Windows (`%VAR_NAME%`) vs macOS/Linux (`$VAR_NAME`). Instead, we pass the name of the environment variable and the validation script reads the variable's value off of `process.env`.

##
This is an alternative to #36497.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(dev-infra): fix commit message validation in git worktrees" (#36507)

Issues.Title: build: version from git tag which consists two or more digits
Issues.Body:
Currently, we can't publish v10 because the `--match` pattern in describe can't match the tag `v10.0.0`. The new glob has the following semantics:

```
v[0-9]*.[0-9]*.[0-9]*
# start with a "v" and a number
# followed by 0 or more characters
# followed by a "." and a number
# followed by 0 or more characters
# followed by a "." and a number
# followed by 0 or more characters
```

Couldn't make it stricter because didn't find an easy way to enable extglobs for git for everyone.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: version from git tag which consists two or more digits" (#17424)

Issues.Title: Dev builds in Angular 9 are very slow
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, not present in 8.2. ### Description Dev builds in Angular 9 are _very_ slow. Builds of 8.2 took on average 30 seconds or so, and recompiles took 2-5 seconds. This same app in Angular 9, however, takes ~45-60 seconds to build initially, and recompiles take ~15-25 seconds even if nothing changes at all. Production builds are roughly 5-10 seconds faster in 9, so those are better at least. (Note that none of these times include `ngcc`, that's taken care of before I attempt to build.) Additionally, the speed is slow regardless of whether Ivy is used or not. The Angular 9 build always seems to freeze for a bit at a certain point. It frequently lists the same file, but it's not always the same file that it seems to get stuck on. There's nothing special about the file it usually lists, it's actually quite small and has no advanced Angular or TypeScript features. I found #34699 (and #33532 by extension), but those are unrelated. I'm using TS 3.8 and it happens regardless of the value of that option in `tsconfig.json`. Is there a way I can audit what's causing it to take so long? I tried `ng build --watch --verbose`, but it provides way more information than I can feasibly parse (and also doesn't include timings from what I can tell). ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I'm running `ng build --watch` in both Angular 8 and 9. This is a work app so I can't share it, and I can't provide a repro because I don't know what's causing it to happen in the first place. ## üî• Exception or Error N/A ## üåç Your Environment 
Angular CLI: 9.1.0
Node: 13.12.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 9.1.0

Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)

### Is this a regression?
Yes, the previous version in which the bug was not present with Angular CLI 8.2.2

### Description & Minimal Reproduction

External schematics executed with

`ng g @myorg/some.package`

does not work in Angular 9 anymore. 
The problem seem to be the module resolution with packages that have a dot in it.
Renaming the package without a dot to @myorg/some-package fixes the issue and the CLI executes correctly the schematic. But it would be nice if the module resolution will be working again with dots.

Issues.Title: localized components containing i18n tags will produce identical chunk hashes when building with --localize
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Description I have an application that is being translated in several (21 at the moment) languages using the Angular i18n mechanism. I'm compiling the app AOT, therefore I need a separate build for each locale. To achieve this I setup my Azure pipeline to build the app using multiple agents in parallel, one for each locale, and it works like a charm. However, this is very resource-consuming, so I'm updating to Angular 9 in order to use the `--localize` option, which perfectly fits my needs. After the update I can build the app once and translate it to all languages in a few seconds, which is amazing. I am now facing this issue: when I build my application for all locales, the resulting chunk hashes are identical. As a result, browser cache is not invalidated and files are not re-requested, so the app is not translated. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction - clone this [repo](https://github.com/nas90/i18n-hash-issue) - run `npm install` - run `ng build --localize` - check the dist folder: file content for `main.js` is different for each locale (template text is translated), while the hashes are the same ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 9.1.0
Node: 10.19.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 9.1.0
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, localize, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

typescript                        3.8.3

**Anything else relevant?** In my scenario, the user language preference is stored in the cookies, and a shell app serves the corresponding folder. I can't add the locale to the URL. Therefore in my `angular.json` I set `baseHref="/"` for all locales. I am aware of this [issue](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/16526) and the [PR](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/16817) mentioned there, however the issue is still not resolved.

Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request
Ability to build multiple index.html

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [ ] new
- [X] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
I am working on solution for multi branding app where every branch requires a unique theme with some brand specific configuration. Now in order to support this there is a brand specific environment configuration in place and a separate build needs to be triggered. This is all going good but the problem is as the number of brand grows maintaining branch specific environment and build is getting tedious considering the fact that every brand will also require dev,qa,prod specific configuration. 


### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
The solution that i am looking for is to be able to generate multiple index.html files for each brand from the build with the respective theme reference. I can then use this output in a webserver where i can route it respective index.html based on the domain 

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
I can achieve this by extending the web pack configuration or using gulp but it will be more of workaround rather than a solution as i have to make copies of index.html and also replace the references. It will be nicer to have this feature come from angular cli

Issues.Title: using image [src] with require to load images requires .default suffix
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: angular & cli <9.1.0 ### Description binding image [src] to a source using "require()" longer works unless ".default' suffix is present; ex: ```ts export class TestComponent { sun = require('./sun.svg'); // [...] ``` ``` html ``` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. setup the test app ```bash ng new test-app curl -Ll https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e8/Heraldic_Sun.svg -o ./test-app/src/app/sun.svg cd test-app ng serve ``` 2. edit app.component.ts ```ts import { Component } from '@angular/core'; declare const require: any; @Component({ selector: 'app-root', templateUrl: './app.component.html', styleUrls: ['./app.component.scss'] }) export class AppComponent { sun = require('./sun.svg'); } ``` and replace app.component.html with ```html ``` ## üî• Exception or Error there will be no exception however rather than requiring the img a request to http://localhost:4200/[object%20Module] will be made; changing the require like this: ```ts sun = require('./sun.svg').default; ``` works however previously it worked without this; this gets fixed if [file-loader's esModule](https://webpack.js.org/loaders/file-loader/#esmodule) is set to false which i did using a custom angular-builders/custom-webpack like this ```js const isImgLoader = (rule) => rule.test && rule.loader && rule.test.toString().includes('svg') && rule.loader.toString().includes('file-loader'); const patchFileLoader = (rule) => ({ ...rule, options: { ...rule.options, esModule: false, // <------ here }, }); module.exports = (config) => { return { ...config, module: { ...config.module, rules: config.module.rules.map((r) => isImgLoader(r) ? patchFileLoader(r) : r ), }, }; }; ``` ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: Duplicate files in dist folder after ng build
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? ### Description Hi. Issues.Title: CdkVirtualScrollViewport rendered range is not correct when going from a large list to a smaller list
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:

The rendered range is not set to the expected value when changing from a longer data list to a shorter one. I think this only happens if you are at the very top of the list (i.e. the rendered range start is 0).

#### What is the expected behavior?

The end of the rendered range shouldn't be higher than the length of the data list.

#### What is the current behavior?

If the start of the rendered range is 0, and it is changing to a smaller list than the previous one, the end of the rendered range doesn't change. This causes the rendered range to be higher than the length of the data. Also, another issue is that because the rendered range doesn't change at all in this case, there will be no emitted event to the `viewChange` property on `CdkVirtualForOf`.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-virtual-scroll-issue


#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?

I'm swapping out lists to show search results in the virtual scroll, and I implemented an infinite scroll based on subscribing to `viewChange` in `DataSource.connect()`. This issue is causing the `viewChange` event to not get emitted in a situation where I think it should be, so I am not able to react to an event and load more data into the list.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

I'm on these versions currently in my project, but I'm fairly certain this behavior has existed many versions back:
Material: 8.2.3
Angular: 8.2.14
TypeScript: 3.5.3

#### Is there anything else we should know?

I believe the issue is somewhere in the calculations in `FixedSizeVirtualScroll._updateRenderedRange`: https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/cdk/scrolling/fixed-size-virtual-scroll.ts#L118-L152.


I think I have a workaround directive, but I'm not sure if it will cause other issues:
The directive subscribes to the `dataStream` of `CdkVirtualForOf`, and if the end of the rendered range for the viewport is greater than the data length for the event, then I make a call like this: `CdkVirtualScrollViewport.setRenderedRange({start: previousStart, end: data.length})`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "CdkVirtualScrollViewport rendered range is not correct when going from a large list to a smaller list" (#19029)

Issues.Title: fix(progress-bar): unable to change value through property setter
Issues.Body:
Fixes the progress bar not updating when its value is changed through the setter. Normally we don't really handle cases like this, but I decided to do it in this one, because:

1. We were already paying the payload price for the setter anyway so adding the `markForCheck` call won't be too expensive.
2. The progress bar is a bit of a special case where it might make sense not to go through the view to change a value. E.g. for something like a file upload where everything is being done in memory.

Fixes #18676.

Issues.Title: refactor: all-typography mixin should use all-theme to avoid code duplication
Issues.Body:
As discussed in our team meeting, we want to get rid of the duplication of
individual theme, color, density and typography mixins
(similar to how we did it for all-density and all-color).

We couldn't simplify the all-typography mixin because the `core-theme`
mixin is stored in a file that relies on `all-typography`. This causes
a circular dependency when `all-typography` would then rely on `all-theme`.

To fix this, we split the `mat-core-theme` and `mat-core` mixin into
separate files. This avoids the circular dependency. Additionally, a test
has been created that ensures that the theming bundle still exposes the
necessary mixins/variables as needed.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor: all-typography mixin should use all-theme to avoid code duplication" (#19021)

Issues.Title: bug(cdk/overlay): BlockScrollStrategy should work if underlay becomes scrollable later
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

StackBlitz [example](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-kz7d9w?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts).

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open the example linked to above.
2. A list will appear beneath an overlay displaying a spinner.
3. You can scroll the list despite `BlockScrollStrategy` being used.
4. Now go to the `ngOnInit` method in `app.component.ts` and...
    * Comment out the line `this.spinnerOverlay.open();`
    * Uncomment the preceding line using `timer`.
5. Now the list cannot be scrolled - as expected and required.
 
#### Expected Behavior

I'm aware of #10841 so I know this is understood behavior but I don't understand why it's not considered a bug. Why does it make sense that `BlockScrollStrategy` should only work if whatever is behind the overlay is _already_ scrollable but not work if it becomes scrollable after the overlay is visible?

In my real scenario, I have an empty list, I show the spinner overlay and request the data to fill the list - the data comes back and various other things then happen, i.e. the overlay remains visible. So at this point, I have an overlay over a filled list and it should not be possible to scroll the list while things are still being done and the overlay is still visible.

If this really is the desired behavior for `BlockScrollStrategy` then how should I be handling this situation? I.e. what should I do if I know the content is not currently scrollable when the overlay is displayed but will become scrollable while the overlay is still visible?

#### Actual Behavior

The actual behavior is that the background list is scrollable, as described above, despite using `BlockScrollStrategy`.

#### Environment

- Angular: 9.1.1
- CDK/Material: 9.1.1
- Browser: Chrome 80
- Operating System: macOS Catalina and Ubuntu 18.04
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(cdk/overlay): BlockScrollStrategy should work if underlay becomes scrollable later" (#19020)

Issues.Title: bug(cdkScrollingModule): No list-items using server-side-rendering (angular-universal)
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
When using angular-universal's server-side-rendering in combination with the `cdkScrollingModule` the rendered html-document returned by the server never contains any list-items.

_Reason why this happens:_  
During the rendering process on the server the variable `elementRef` in the component `cdkVirtualScrollViewport` has no property called `clientHeight` nor `scrollTop`.

As a result the method `updateRenderedRange` sets `scrollOffset` and `viewportSize` to _undefined_ which leads to a wrong renderedRange.

#### What is the expected behavior?
There should be a (configurable) fallback value if those essential properties are missing, so the document that is sent to the client contains at least some list-elements.

#### What is the current behavior?
The rendered document does not contain any list-items.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
1. Set up an angular-universal app
2. Import the ScrollingModule of `@angular/cdk`
3. Disable the execution of JavaScript on the client (that only the html-document returned by the server is shown)
4. Request the page containing the list

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?
Due to the server-side-rendering the user sees the website much faster (while the angular-application still loads) but it only shows an empty list which is not quite useful.  
As a result the whole performance-boost brought with angular-universal is lost.

#### Environment
Angular: 9.1.0
CDK/Material: 9.2.0
Browser(s): Chromium 80.0.3987.162
Operating System: Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(cdkScrollingModule): No list-items using server-side-rendering (angular-universal)" (#19012)

Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Is it possible to add beginDateSelectedChange feature of sat-calendar to the datepicker-input?

#### Use Case

The need arises in cases when we want to restrict the user to a selected end date based on the begin date selected by the user. Currently there are only two Event Emitter supported by the datepicker-input that are (dateChange) and (dateInput) both of which fires event after both begin and end date are selected, which does not fullfill the current requirement.
Is there any future scope to add the feature to date-picker Input also?

Issues.Title: refactor: decouple migrations from CLI devkit
Issues.Body:
We want to refactor our update-tool to no longer rely
on specifics from the Angular CLI devkit. This has various benefits:

* Ability to run migrations inside Google.
* Ability to run migrations in a standalone tool (for people not using the CLI)
* No tight dependency on the CLI devkit API. We could easily switch tools if needed.
* Ability to wrap migrations in tslint rules (or other tools if needed).

Additionally, this PR fixes an issue with Bazel on Windows where runfiles no longer can be resolved. This is because `rules_nodejs` symlinks the workspace into the `@npm` repository now, and resolving runfiles through relative paths no longer works.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor: decouple migrations from CLI devkit" (#19014)

Issues.Title: help(SnackBar): Electron and Snackbar don't work well together
Issues.Body:
<!--------

The Angular team can't provide general troubleshooting help. However, the extended community of
users can provide more help: 

StackOverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/angular-material2
Gitter: https://gitter.im/angular/material2
Google Groups: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/angular-material2

Issues should capture only bug reports and feature requests. However, we understand that 
it is not always clear whether an issue is caused by a bug or incorrect usage of a feature/component.

Most support requests will be automatically closed. If the answer is quickly obvious, though, we 
might be able to provide a brief answer.

-------->


#### What are you trying to do?

I'm building an Electron Desktop application using Angular Material. When communicating with the back end of the app to get information, sending it to the front end of the app and displaying that data via snackbar. To listen for the event on the front end (getting the data from the back to the front) I use the listener for `ipcRenderer` like so

```ts
this.ipc.render.on('test', (e, res) => {
	snackbar.open(res, 'close')
})
```

this works somewhat. For some reason, it auto-positions it to the top left. Clicking the action button will make it snap to the default original position or to the position in the config, if you have one set. Then the action button will do nothing after this, after clicking anywhere on the app except the action button, it'll disappear. If there is no action button set, it will not disappear.

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?
The first line in this example down below will work perfectly fine and will use the config. The one inside the listener wont apply the config until after the action button is clicked and then clicked outside of it (as stated before) 
```ts
snackbar.open(res, 'close', config)
this.ipc.render.on('test', (e, res) => {
	snackbar.open(res, 'close', config)
})
```


#### Reproduction

I have tried to recreate this in StackBlitz as at first I thought it was having trouble updating the view or communicating with the service and components, but it seems to be between Electron and snackbar specifically (all other components don't have troubling relaying data from Electron).
  
I can make a git here soon for reproduction (I recreated a lot of my app from the ground up to only hit this again)
#### Environment

- Angular: 9.0.7
- CDK/Material: 9.2.0
- Browser(s): Electron/Chromium
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "help(SnackBar): Electron and Snackbar don't work well together" (#19011)

Issues.Title: bug: Memory Leaks on several material components ?
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-x9pcfz

Hello, I have an application where I make massive use of material components and I found that my application had memory leaks. 

I created an empty Angular 8.2.14 application and imported inside some material components that I use to test them. Here is what the application looks like:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32635415/78660797-0292e980-78ce-11ea-93e1-c8d3c107b0bd.png)
Source code here: https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-x9pcfz

For each components I implemented with Selenium a test scenario containing interactions that are repeated 1000 times. Here are the list of interactions for each tested components:
- `mat-ripple`: Tap the `RIPPLE` button.
- `mat-menu`: Tap the `OPEN MENU` label and then tap `MENU ITEM`  in the opened menu to close the menu.
- `mat-slide-toggle`: Tap twice `SLIDE TOGGLE` to switch states.
- `mat-checkbox`: Tap twice `CHECKBOX` to switch states.
- `mat-radio`: Tap twice `RADIO` to switch states.
- `mat-stepper`: Tap three times `NEXT` button to go across the 3 steps.
- `mat-slider`: Tap `MINUS` button to decrease slider and then tap `PLUS` button to increase the slider.

Before testing a component 1000 times, Chromium is restarted with following option: `-js-flags=--gc-global=true, --expose-gc=true` in incognito mode.
The test wait 1 second after each tap.
At the end of each iteration, the test record the current JS heap size using `window.memory.usedJSHeapSize`.
Each 10 iterations, `window.gc()` is performed to force Major Garbage Collector and then the test wait 60 seconds.
(Yes it took 15 hours to run those tests.)

Here the graph we can plot from the heap size for each scenarios:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32635415/78662153-3707a500-78d0-11ea-88fd-78d13307192f.png)

A more friendly graph with polynomial smoothing:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32635415/78662104-222b1180-78d0-11ea-85e2-cecf5137d549.png)

My goal here is not to make finger pointing, I like Material since it is pretty simple to use. I am opened to any suggestions to make my tests more reliable or to change the way I am using material components.
 
#### Expected Behavior

Memory to be stable over time and not increasing.

#### Actual Behavior

Memory seems to increase for each tested components.

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.14
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
- Browser(s): Chromium 78.0.3904.108
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug: Memory Leaks on several material components ?" (#19010)

Issues.Title: bug(Mat-icon/Mat-Stepper): Accessibility issue whiel reading Mat-icon
Issues.Body:
JAWS Screen reader is having issues while reading the content on 2nd step.

Steps to reproduce:
1. create stepper on page with three steps on it
2. On first step add field with mat-icon, icon should clickable with dynamic aria label

 
 
#### Expected Behavior
JAWS screen reader has option to read all the content of page. while reading content on 2nd stepper it should not read the content of 1st step.

#### Actual Behavior
JAWS screen reader is reading the mat-icon aria label of 1st stepper in 2nd stepper. This happen only in case when screen reader reads the total content of the screen(insert+v)

https://angular-material-7-sandbox-en8aoh.stackblitz.io/
##### Detail Explaination

We are using angular material stepper. On first page of stepper, JAWs is reading all the fields correctly. First page has a field with Icon . Field is having dynamic aria-label which can change on some condition. 
 
On read all (insert + down arrow), Its reading field and clickable icon of it along with icon Aria label. So no problem here.
Problem starts on 2nd page, when user filled the information on 1st step and moved to 2nd step(fill your address). When start read all(insert + down arrow). Its reading aria label of icon on first step(not whole page only icon).
Those icons(aria-label) are not present 2nd step even. This is happening only when aria-label is dynamic not when aria-label is static.
The same issue on 3rd step. Its reading dynamic aria-label of icon on first page and second page.

#### Environment

- Angular: 7.3.7
- CDK/Material:7.3.7
- Browser(s):
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(Mat-icon/Mat-Stepper): Accessibility issue whiel reading Mat-icon" (#19009)

Issues.Title: fix(material-experimental/mdc-chips) Replace default values
Issues.Body:
mat-chip-grid implements ControlValueAccessor. Its default value
right now is undefined; once a chip is added, its value is an array
of all the chip values. The default value for a given chip is all the
text content inside the chip. For chips with icons, this causes the
icon text to be included in the value, so a row chip using matChipRemove
would have a value like " hello cancel ". (There's also some unwanted
whitespace in the textContent).

Replace undefined with an empty array, and the textContent with just
the actual chip text, which in the case of row chips corresponds to the
text that the user entered.

These unintuitive values are the same as the old non-mdc
mat-chip-listbox. But due to the way the old listbox implemented
ControlValueAccessor, chips being used as a chip grid didn't actually
ever call the onChange handler to update the FormControl value, so their
values were basically ignored.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(material-experimental/mdc-chips) Replace default values" (#19006)

Issues.Title: refactor: decouple migrations from CLI devkit
Issues.Body:
We want to refactor our update-tool to no longer rely
on specifics from the Angular CLI devkit. This has various benefits:

* Ability to run migrations inside Google.
* Ability to run migrations in a standalone tool (for people not using the CLI!)
* No tight dependency on the CLI devkit API. We could easily switch tools if needed.
* Ability to wrap migrations in tslint rules (or other tools).
* And potentially more. These are just the ones that came to mind yet.

This will be the foundation for our MDC migrations that should run within CLI projects and inside Google. Optionally we can provide a standalone CLI tool that runs the migrations too!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor: decouple migrations from CLI devkit" (#19004)

Issues.Title: bug(drag-drop + virtual scroll): Draggable item loses its position when new list item is rendered in the DOM as a result of virtual scrolling
Issues.Body:
### Reproduction The problem comes up with you mix together drag-and-drop and virtual scroll functionality. [Here's the stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/fork/angular-ixqfux) that demonstrates the problem. I've painted the placeholder element into green. **I've done a lot of debugging to figure out the cause of the problem and I'll describe my findings below.** Steps to reproduce: 1. Configure component view to use both drag-and-drop and virtual scrolling ```
{{item.id}}
 ``` 2. Star dragging an element down. ### Expected Behavior A draggable item is always rendered where I keep a mouse pointer. ### Actual Behavior As new elements are being rendered to the DOM, the draggable item loses its position and either disappears or starts jumping in the list. ### Environment - Angular: 9.0.5 - CDK/Material: 9.2.0 - Browser(s): Chrome - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows ### Demo of the problem: ![2020-04-06_14-50-54](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6124091/78556550-d6b52c80-7817-11ea-82da-50c0caa4f7b9.gif) ### My investigation The cause of the problem seems to be the new items that are being rendered. Once an item is added to the DOM, the `CdkDrag` directive attached to it [registers itself within a drop list container](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/d1a6ea74db0881001bf02ff113f269552effc4f6/src/cdk/drag-drop/directives/drop-list.ts#L197). This in turn leads to the `withItems` method being triggered on the drop container list: ![image (2)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6124091/78557328-3eb84280-7819-11ea-82ed-738bfeb860e4.png) As the callstack unfolds, the [cacheItemPositions](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/531ea7cc5b2a6c13daac59c3b33f00ff1147efe7/src/cdk/drag-drop/drop-list-ref.ts#L606) method is called. The problem is that inside this method all current item positions (offsets) are reset to 0. If you add a logging to the method before and after `this._this._itemPositions` are updated: ``` this._itemPositions.forEach(item => console.log('Element ID:', item.drag.data.element.nativeElement.id, 'offset:', item.offset)); ``` this is what the console shows: ![2020-04-06_14-58-16](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6124091/78557564-aec6c880-7819-11ea-92fe-3ecfe98d7bc3.jpg) This leads to a placeholder element lose current position and start jumping in the list. **I'm happy to make a PR to fix it, if I get guidance on the best way to address this problem.**
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(drag-drop + virtual scroll): Draggable item loses its position when new list item is rendered in the DOM as a result of virtual scrolling" (#19003)

Issues.Title: bug(drag-drop): `Point` interface is not exported in the public API
Issues.Body:
#### Issue
The `Point` interface:
```ts
/** Point on the page or within an element. */
export interface Point {
  x: number;
  y: number;
}
```
is defined and exported inside [drag-ref.ts](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/cdk/drag-drop/drag-ref.ts). This interface is used in the public drag-drop API, e.g.
```ts
@Input('cdkDragConstrainPosition')
constrainPosition: (point: Point, dragRef: DragRef) => Point
```

But `Point` is missing from the [public-api.ts](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/cdk/drag-drop/public-api.ts) exports.

```ts
export {DragRef, DragRefConfig} from './drag-ref';
```

...should include `Point` as well.

```ts
export {DragRef, DragRefConfig, Point} from './drag-ref';
```

#### Environment

- Angular:
- CDK/Material: 9.2
- Browser(s):
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(drag-drop): `Point` interface is not exported in the public API" (#19001)

Issues.Title: bug(cdkTextareaAutosize): Animation of height calculates default height wrongly
Issues.Body:
I have a component, A, which contains a textarea, which has the attribute cdkTextareaAutosize.

When I animate the height of A from 0 to * (i.e. the default height). The height of A is animated to the wrong final value which appears like the default height assumes that the height of the textarea is only one line and not the number of lines it actually has.

As soon as the animation completes, the height jumps to the right height.

Therefore I guess, that there is a kind of synchronization problem between computing the height of the textarea by the cdkTextareaAutosize attribute and determining the default height for '*'.

Any hint?

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.14.
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3.
- Browser(s): Google Chrome.
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  Windows 10 Pro
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(cdkTextareaAutosize): Animation of height calculates default height wrongly" (#18999)
